posts.name: James
posts.cooked: Our team is leaning towards using an elevator to place coral as high as L4, what kind of encoder do you use to track position of the elevator? Do you use and absolute encoder? Or the integrated encoder in the motor?
You can use the integrated encoder; if so you’ll want some way to set the offset, whether that’s a limit switch, a hard stop, or starting the robot with the elevator in the same place every time.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: Then would you translate rotations to elevator height somehow?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FTC 6603 Project Manager | Former Disruptive Innovator FRC 6317

posts.custom_user_title: FTC 6603 Project Manager | Former Disruptive Innovator FRC 6317

posts.name: Ashton Demmer
posts.cooked: Yes you can math out the height. Just use the number of encoder ticks and the gear ratio used.

posts.name: Cr1spyBacon8r
posts.cooked: In the past, we’ve used a string potentiometer, which handles exact positioning, while also dealing with issues you’ll get with any slack you get on the strings/chains that lift the elevator.

posts.name: Chris LaSalle
posts.cooked: Try using a Lasercan from Grapple Robotics/listed on The Thriftybot. Just use a reflector on the top of the elevator. You can easily set the elevator varying hights and top & bottom limits.

posts.name: Joseph Gonzalo Amador
posts.cooked: For feedforward control of the elevator, would you get the velocity from the motor encoder and then use the lasercan for the position?

I wouldn’t do this, adding the lasercan to the system unnecessarily adds latency and discretization error to the control system which severely degrades performance. The internal encoder will give you accurate enough data much faster, which is significantly easier to design controllers for.

suggested_topics.fancy_title: Swerve wheels spinning different directions after assigning CanCoder ID’s
suggested_topics.title: Swerve wheels spinning different directions after assigning CanCoder ID's
suggested_topics.excerpt: We solved it. Our cancoder ID’s were not aligned with our spark max id’s therefore causing the issue
